2016 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/01/2016
I loved living here....I usually leave a review when its bad but the staff is so nice here I had to say something. I had no problems with my move in .Anything i needed fixed was fixed in a timely manner. The staff is really helpful, the leasing manager worked with me on a few late payments. I haven't had any real problems living here but I would like to see more visitors parking.I also suggest finding a room mate before moving in, it makes things easier. It sucks that im relocating, I enjoyed staying here.

The landlord refuses to reframe our door after it was broken into nearly a year ago. The front door is not secure. The landlord tried to tell me that the loose strike plate (the metal part that the deadbolt sits in) is "cosmetic" (it's not - it's literally half of the locking mechanism). The door was splintered during the break-in, and instead of reframing the door, they merely screwed the splintered parts back together. DO NOT RENT FROM HERE! I made a big mistake coming here, and will leave as soon as either my lease is up, or I can break it.

Report
Resident
2012 - 2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/28/2015
I have had the unfortunate circumstances of having to live here for 3 years while I finished law school. This place is horrible and if possible stay away from it. They have had 5 different property managers since I have been here. There is too many hands touching rental payments and they always swear money come up missing. I always keep my money order receipt and when they found out I knew the law (after I threatened to press charges for embezzlement) they suddenly found the rental payments. No one is ever on one accord. The office staff will tell you ten different things. They are quick to act without proper notice but expect you to give them all types of notice. The property need renovations but the company that own it is too cheap to do anything. All of the electrical work is old and poses fire hazards. The units are cheaply thrown together and many contain mold. During the summer it is always noisy and the parking lot is frequently visited by Durham PD. When Durham PD is needed they are never here but they are forever cruising through the area and spying on residents. The security (renta-cop) is personally a jerk and is hungry for authority. I watch how he and the front office conspire to take advantage of poor college kids. Towing happens here more frequently than crime in America. We have more parking spaces than residents but yet only 20 parking spots in the whole complex designated visitor. The tow truck is called every 15 minutes and the shady rent-a-cop parks his car behind college kids who ran in and out of a unit, in order to prevent them from leaving. If you are looking for a place that's never quiet, fraudulent management, harassing want to be cops, poor infrastructure and obsessive towing worries then this place is for you, but to anyone with common sense PLEASE STAY AWAY.

Report
Resident
2014 - 2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/21/2015
Please do NOT move here! I know like most students this may seem like the best options because it is all inclusive. Which is exactly what I thought! I am a student at NCCU and was not looking to move into dorms simply because of the rules. However, don't be fooled!!!! When I signed my lease in August and asked could I see my apartment before move they claimed it wasn't ready and all new residents move in on the same day. Which is CRAP! I also had to pay full rent for the ENTIRE month of August but didn't move in until the middle of August on the 16th. I find that quite ODD. I signed my lease for $671 PER ROOM with a $30 concession and $40 electric and water cap that varied per month because they did not completely explain the "all utilities included" rule. Meaning if you water and electric don't go over $40 you have no overages. I've paid almost $800 for one month before. Let alone a week after moving in there were flyers tapped to my door about resigning my lease, threatening emails that my room would be reassigned. The maintenance comes in your apartment whenever they like.. The most you'll know is that they came by the conformation email. However, this does not mean your problem has been fixed. My dryer takes around 2-3 on high to completely dry a full size load of clothes, garabe disposal has gone out several times, kitchen cabinet fell off, several lights in my kitchen and dining area do not work, A/C unit stopped working took almost two days for someone to come look at it. I advise all students to PLEASE ask someone who has lived here for their experience before signing a lease. Your rent CAN & WILL go up at any time, parking for any guests you have will be a hassle. The "on sight" police have harassed and just walked in my house here before. It is the summer time and the pool closes at 8 on weekdays and 5 on weekends. They say they cater to us students specifically.... I completely beg to differ and can't not wait until July to move!

Report
Resident
2014 - 2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 02/28/2015
I am really disappointed in these apartments. I did NOT go into renting here expecting the world, or a lot at all, because it caters to college students. The fact that they have full-size washers and dryers in the apartments already made them a step above living in a dorm. All they seem to care about is people resigning their leases for next year. I was hounded within a WEEK of moving in to resign my lease. A WEEK. I have never lived in an apartment complex that had to resign a lease so early before. I won't be making a decision until 90 days before my lease expires, like normal renters, because I want to experience living here before I make that decision. I've gotten so many threatening letters from Level 51ten that if I don't resign in 24, 48, 72 hours, they will reassign my room to someone else when the lease is up. Being pushy with me makes me less inclined to even consider resigning because already I am not happy with the complex. Already I have qualms because they can't even give me an access card and I've been here almost 3 months. They keep saying "we've contacted the company that does them, blah blah." Well, if they STILL haven't fixed the problem in 3 months, you should probably be looking at another company to service your needs. Just saying. Walls are paper thin. I can hear not only my roommates but my neighbors as well. Another point against Level 51ten. Compared to other complexes, they are expensive for no reason, even with utilities included. Their "gym" is outdated and much of the equipment is falling apart and needs to be replaced. There is SO MUCH POT SMOKING going on in this complex... another reason I will be moving once my lease it up. My roommates, neighbors, etc smoke so much that as soon as I walk into my apartment or building you can smell it. It's gross and I can't be around that crap. They do roommate matching, but just like in dorms, it is hit or miss. My roommates and I are like oil and water so that is another reason why I don't want to stay. I don't want to resign and get stuck living with them for another year. I asked the office if I could resign and get assigned a different room and they told me it would cost $300 to transfer, and $300 for a cleaning fee for my old room. That's a month's rent that I might as well keep and move to another complex where I don't have to deal with this crap. As for that "cleaning fee" ... When I moved in, the room hadn't even been cleaned properly. THERE WAS STILL HAIR IN THE SHOWER DRAIN. The carpet had most definitely NOT even been vacuumed and the windows were filthy. I would really like to know what that "cleaning" entailed for such a price, considering they charge it to everyone upon move-out supposedly. The internet service here is God-awful and is slow so much of the time it's really difficult to get anything accomplished. You're stuck with Time Warner, so you just have to grin and bear it. Overall, I would tell a prospective renter to run in the other direction when looking for a new apartment.

I won't be making a decision until 90 days before my lease expires, like normal renters, because I want to experience living here before I make that decision. I've gotten so many threatening letters from Level 51ten that if I don't resign in 24, 48, 72 hours, they will reassign my room to someone else when the lease is up. Being pushy with me makes me less inclined to even consider resigning because already I am not happy with the complex. Already I have qualms because they can't even give me an access card and I've been here almost 3 months. They keep saying "we've contacted the company that does them, blah blah." Well, if they STILL haven't fixed the problem in 3 months, you should probably be looking at another company to service your needs. Just saying. Walls are paper thin. I can hear not only my roommates but my neighbors as well. Another point against Level 51ten. Compared to other complexes, they are expensive for no reason, even with utilities included. Their "gym" is outdated and much of the equipment is falling apart and needs to be replaced. There is SO MUCH POT SMOKING going on in this complex... another reason I will be moving once my lease it up. My roommates, neighbors, etc smoke so much that as soon as I walk into my apartment or building you can smell it. It's gross and I can't be around that crap. They do roommate matching, but just like in dorms, it is hit or miss. My roommates and I are like oil and water so that is another reason why I don't want to stay. I don't want to resign and get stuck living with them for another year. I asked the office if I could resign and get assigned a different room and they told me it would cost $300 to transfer, and $300 for a cleaning fee for my old room. That's a month's rent that I might as well keep and move to another complex where I don't have to deal with this crap. As for that "cleaning fee" ... When I moved in, the room hadn't even been cleaned properly. THERE WAS STILL HAIR IN THE SHOWER DRAIN. The carpet had most definitely NOT even been vacuumed and the windows were filthy. I would really like to know what that "cleaning" entailed for such a price, considering they charge it to everyone upon move-out supposedly. The internet service here is God-awful and is slow so much of the time it's really difficult to get anything accomplished. You're stuck with Time Warner, so you just have to grin and bear it. Overall, I would tell a prospective renter to run in the other direction when looking for a new apartment. Read less

2013 - 2014 Not Recommended Reviewed 04/17/2014
I am currently living at Level 51ten Apartments. When I first viewed the apartments everything seemed so great. They offered us a $500 credit that we could put towards our rent, no application fee, etc. The show room was nice, but what "show room" isn't? Overall, I would not recommend these apartments. They're so money hungry; almost every night they have Tow companies out here towing visitors or putting boots on their cars. There is a police officer for the grounds, but he literally sits in one spot in his car for the three hours he's out there. The staff is friendly, but overall are knowledge deficient. One staff member can tell us one thing, and the next will tell us something completely different. They're not on one accord at all. The management is not helpful in answering questions and is not in the office when she's supposed to be. And DON'T BELIEVE ANYTHING THEY TELL YOU ABOUT DEALS! IT'S NOT TRUE. I was supposed to get a $500 credit to put towards my rent throughout the duration of my lease. I used $200 of it once, and then they increased my rent from $585-$605 without prior warning. And on top of that, they told me I could not have the remaining $300. When I went to talk to the manager, she pretty much gave me some -------- explanation, and refused to lower my rent to its previous price. Me and another of my roommates are subleasing our apartment to someone next month. Now out of nowhere, we're charged a $300 cleaning cost so they can clean for the next person! $300! There's no damages, just some nail holes and minor wear; but they don't care. That $300 rate is for everyone, regardless of how clean the room is. The thing that sold us on the apartments were the free shuttles they offered to NCCU and UNC, but there so unreliable. They don't have many bus drivers, so when one calls out or is late they just don't run the shuttles. Residents don't even receive a courtesy message so they'll waste their time waiting for a shuttle that never comes. Save yourself a headache. Don't move here.

The icing on the cake, however, is the kickback the apartment complex receives from the Roadside Towing company in Durham. Regardless if there is ample parking, if you don't have a sticker/permit your car will be towed unless it is parked in one of the very scarce and secluded 'visitor parking' spaces. These spaces are usually taken by victims of Roadside Towing who are now enlighted, after paying $160 to get their car back from the sketchy lot in downtown Durham. Its happened to residents and visitors alike, as late in the night as 11pm. With that said, drive away from Levl 51 ten Student Apartments and never look back. 2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/11/2012
I really can't stand this place, either before or after. My boyfriend lived here briefly while it was still the Verge, and he hated it. The housemate that he was matched with was sloppy and inconsiderate (to say the least), and the furnishings were low-quality, almost what you'd expect in a dorm room. It was a college community then, and it's a college community now. Due to unforeseen circumstances, we had to find a new and cheap place to live recently, and we decided to look at the Verge, recently renovated to Level 51 Ten. They were under new management, promised new hard-wood floors, updated appliances, and a much better experience. HA. Housemate issues aside, we're still very dissatisfied. We have only been here a short time, and we've already had to call the cops for night-time noise complaints multiple times (because the girl blasting her music refuses to cooperate, no matter how nicely we've asked, or how much we've put up with during the afternoon). Those "hard-wood floors" that we were promised weren't put in for a month, and when they were, they weren't hard wood. They were vinyl, decorated to *look* like hard wood. Don't get me wrong, it's better than what was in there before, but they SAID hard wood, and that was one of our deciding factors. I don't appreciate false advertising. The appliances are cheap and clearly not efficient (no Energy Star ratings here!); our refrigerator needs to be replaced, because it doesn't keep the fridge cool, but the freezer is covered in solid ice. Seriously. The housemate's toilet didn't work when he moved in, so THAT had to be fixed... The place obviously hadn't been professionally cleaned (or even cleaned at all?) judging by the layers of dust everywhere, the splatters of tomato sauce all over the kitchen, and the ample amounts of the previous tenant's hair clogging all of our bathroom drains. The bed is ridiculously uncomfortable, the lock is almost impossible to jam the key into, the steps and landings are always covered with trash (bottle caps, cigarettes, wrappers, fast food wrappers, etc.... Since we've moved in, we've had problems with the freezer freezing (and the fridge not cooling), as well as with the toilets clogging... wayyyyy more often than any toilet should clog (multiple times a week is not unusual). The internet speeds are awful, there have been multiple parking lot screaming matches between exes, there isn't enough visitor parking, the lighting in the parking lot is nearly non-existent (nighttime walking around here isn't recommended)... I wouldn't recommend living at Level 51 Ten to anyone except broke college kids who like listening to loud rap and hip-hop day in and day out, and who don't care whether their surroundings are clean or not. To add insult to injury, by the way, a member of the leasing office staff has definitely made not-so-subtle advances towards one of us, despite knowing for a fact that we are a committed couple. Not classy, Level 51. Not classy at all.

2010 - 2011 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/06/2012
The Verge looks nice from the outsides and the apartments inside are nice too - especially for an undergrad. The biggest issue with this complex is the people. The noise level was horrible, at all hours of the night, and the walls are incredibly thin. I had the good fortune of living next to people who used to smoke weed 4 or 5 times per week in their apartment. The vents to our apartments were connected, so we had to always keep the laundry room doors closed, otherwise our apartment would smell like weed. Things got even worse during the summer, when people were screaming at the pool at 2:30am, 3:30 am, 4:30am...you get my drift. The grounds and landscaping are nice, but there is trash EVERYWHERE. My next door neighbor let his dog crap in the middle of the stairs in January...the crap was still there when I moved out in June. They have a "strict" but unenforced pet policy (which is why there were two pit-bulls living next door whose owners never walked them on a leash). Oh, and did I mention the shooting that occurred the year after I moved out? The bottom line is that they can change the name of the complex, but unless they do a better job of either vetting the people they let move in or enforcing complex rules, this place will not be a peaceful place to come home to.

0 Not Recommended Reviewed 02/08/2012
Don't even consider this place if you want to live. Seriously check out Cosgrove, Notting Hill, Alta Springs, etc. I lived in a 3br 3ba furnished apartment from August 2011 to November 2011 - and I got out of my lease because there was a shoot out the ranged from outside my door on the third floor to outside my window on the ground - luckily I was home alone because a bullet went through my roommates room and ricocheted all around her room - and a bullet went through my car. Turns out they were making crack cocaine in the apartment across form mine and something went wrong because their friends decided to come kill them. One guy was shot in the leg and a ton of peoples apartments got shot through but luckily no one else got hurt. The verge has had a shooting since - and SEVERAL break-ins. They try to cover these incidents up but check the crime reports - and don't be fooled by new management - they lie through their teeth. And, of course, being shot at was NOT the only problem we had there. I had to call with complaints so many times that I have their number memorized. The residents seem to think 3am on a Tuesday is a cool time to blare rap music - the kind that shakes you awake, and if we could hear/feel it on the highest floor, then I feel really bad for the people below them. Also there were CONSTANT parties - one on a Sunday night that lasted till 5am - even through we called the cops around 2am, and the people got a fined noise violation, their party also spilled out into the parking lot and hallway. And the courtesy officer/security guard is never available. Our neighbors apartments were disgusting and had roaches so we had to constantly stop roaches from crawling under our door. It took two weeks of haggling to get any maintenance done - we didn't even have half the furniture in our contract for the first month - like the TV, bar chairs, dryer, and desk chairs. The apartments were gross to begin with - hair and weave left behind from previous people. After 'cleaning' the apartment before we moved in, they left all the trash they found outside our door and then threatened to charge us for it. It took two weeks after we complained for them to come pick it up. Also residents often didn't take trash to the dumps, just hid it around the building to attract animals, or threw it off their balcony and damaged cars in the parking lot. Trash was often strewn all over the property. You may have heard from those who lived here a few years ago that it was great - well it was, until they chose residents who don't pay rent - don't go to school - and don't care about anyone, which is evident by the drugs, shootings, parties etc - and they have children with them, which is just sad. Also the bus system sucks - they'll come at times that aren't on schedule or not come when they should Also don't be fooled by new management - The old management was HORRIBLE yes, but new management is manipulative and deceiving - they wont tell you about the shootings, and they won't show you your actual apartment ahead of time. They show you a display apartment which looks nothing like the run down apartment you actually get. New management will say they evicted a ton of the old undesirable residents but they also signed a hundred new undesirables - hence the shooting a few weeks ago and continued break-ins. Also when you can about anything - you either get attitude - unhelpful message relaying (since the manager is NEVER THERE - or bull. The most important message is that this place is UNSAFE and just plain gross, it makes me sick that chapel hill is advertising for them. Here are the pictures of the bullet holes in my apartment and my car http://s1069.photobucket.com/albums/u464/erupert/The Verge/ Seriously check out Notting Hill, or Alta Springs. You'll save money and you'll be much safer and happier. Oh and any reviews you read recommending this place are lies - posted by management, no one who lives here likes this place.

I currently live at the verge (I'm only 5 months in to my lease) and I extremely regret moving to these apartments. Here are a couple of events that have unfolded over the past few months... 1. Two of our appliances did not work the day we moved in (the washer and the stove). 2. We (I have two roommates) sat three very small trash bags outside our front door while cleaning one day to take them out to the trash bins later that day, and to our surprise we were charged $25 per bag on our rent for having them out there for a couple of hours. They would not do any negotiating given this was our first offense. I eventually went back and wrote a letter to "Higher management" and never heard anything back. 3. One of my roommates had a motorcycle which was stolen from the apartment complex. I know its not their responsibility to keep it from getting it stolen but they showed no interest in helping out with the matter. This also notes that there is serious crime here already. 4. My vehicle was towed from right outside of my own apartment. We began living here in June and they changed the parking passes in august (with little notice). I work five to six days per week and could hardly get to the main office to pick up a new pass anyway. My vehicle still had the old pass on it when it was getting towed and I even ran out of my apartment when it happened. I could prove by 10 different ways I lived here but nothing was good enough simply because I didn't have the newest pass. I went to the main office but they would do nothing for me. I also know of many other people who went through the same experience. Hard to believe an apartment complex would tow their own residents and not reimburse them the $175 fee for the mistake. 5. I recently discovered that someone was shot here at The Verge a couple of weeks ago. There are police who patrol every once in a while now, but definitely not enough to make it feel safe. 6. And today (12/3/11) I started talking to the people who live across from us who were moving out, and they had said their apartment was broken into less than a week ago through the sliding glass door which is always locked with the bar. The management once again offered no sympathy and at first had no interest in negotiating with their lease so they could move out. They talked to higher management and he offered to give them one free months rent if they stayed, but also said they would have to pay it back if they moved out later on. Eventually they let them break the lease only having to pay this months rent. I really liked this place at first, it seemed nice and the people were nice but that all changed very quick. I don't usually go out of my way to complain about anything but in this situation I felt obligated to share what I have gone through so far. Wish me luck throughout the rest of my lease!

And today (12/3/11) I started talking to the people who live across from us who were moving out, and they had said their apartment was broken into less than a week ago through the sliding glass door which is always locked with the bar. The management once again offered no sympathy and at first had no interest in negotiating with their lease so they could move out. They talked to higher management and he offered to give them one free months rent if they stayed, but also said they would have to pay it back if they moved out later on. Eventually they let them break the lease only having to pay this months rent. I really liked this place at first, it seemed nice and the people were nice but that all changed very quick. I don't usually go out of my way to complain about anything but in this situation I felt obligated to share what I have gone through so far. Wish me luck throughout the rest of my lease! Read less

Resident
2010 - 2011 Not Recommended Reviewed 08/31/2011
Ok, so random crime can happen anywhere, but take a look at the Durham Crime Mapper on the Durham PD website before moving here...SO MANY OFFENSES. When I moved in I was told we had a courtesy officer, but apparently he's gone. Not the fault of The Verge, but after an apartment in my building had the door kicked in, it took and hour for the police to get here. The best part was that this happened in broad daylight, at 5pm. Management was notified of the incident, but didn't bother to come talk to the police nor the residents. Other residents weren't notified that the break-in took place so we could be more careful. We get a million emails about making sure to charge our cell phones in case of bad weather, but they can't send out a courtesy email saying there was a break-in and to make sure we keep our doors locked? As a complex that caters to students, I feel like safety of the residents should be the top priority, but it seems that it didn't even make the list. Cockroaches are everywhere outside on the grounds. My roommate and I have personally found two inside our apartment, in addition to the dozen or so ants we see on a daily basis. Air conditioning was broken about every other day last summer. Maintenance probably made 20 trips to our apartment in 2 months until it was finally decided the unit needed to be replaced. Washing machine was broken for forever. Apparently my first request got lost, so I put in another. I called every other day the first week, and EVERY day the next. During one of these calls, a member of the office staff hung up on me. Someone finally came out, but it was broken again the next day. After another failed attempt to repair it, they brought in a new one from a vacant apartment. Why wasn't this done in the first place? We waited a month, which is about 3 and a half weeks too long. And to top it off it was dirty...I spent a good 30 minutes washing the washing machine to get rid of the hair, scum, soap, everything else left from the previous tenants. All in all though, I don't blame the maintenance workers, I blame their supervisors. BOTTOM LINE: It's too expensive, it isn't safe, it looks like an excellent place to live, but if it isn't backed by excellent service it definitely isn't worth the rent you're paying. I'm sorry I renewed, and in 11 very long months, I will be out of the Verge faster than you can say Indiana Jones.

Resident
2010 - 2011 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/24/2011
The Verge is a complex for students. With that in mind, overall it's a pretty good place to live if you are going to UNC or NCCU. For what you get the rent is a lot cheaper than other complexes although it is quite a bit father from campus. To make up for the distance, they do provide a shuttle (although the timing is awkward). As there are a lot of students, noise can be a bit of a problem, but no worse than other complexes aimed at undergraduate students. Also a new company recently purchased the the Verge. So far, I'm not impressed and am worried that the complex might be going downhill. I, however, am moving out to take a new job, so I won't be able to see for sure what happens. Overall, if you are a student in the area, the Verge is a fine alternative to the dorms. If not, this probably isn't the place for you.

Report
Resident
2007 - 2011 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/08/2011
I have lived in this apartment complex for years, and what started as a very respectable and clean complex with nice staff and decent service has become, I'm sorry to say, a horrible place to live. Management/the people who work in the office constantly promise things and never follow through, whether it's something like calling you back or doing something for you, like cleaning something, etc. It takes repeated calling and bothering to get anything done. Requests submitted for maintenance work, which used to be fulfilled within a day or so, now take several at minimum. There is constantly trash and empty alcohol containers in the stairs and in the streets. The management spends so much time trying to tow people not in visitors spots and give away money, prizes, and free food to make people like them instead of fixing things that need fixing. The main problem, however, is the tenants and their noise level. It used to be mostly college students from UNC here, and buses ran to campus on time, there weren't many out of control parties, and things were pretty decent. Now they bus to two campuses, busing is strained and only on the hour when it used to be every thirty minutes, and honestly, having the bus is why most UNC students chose to live here, so shafting us in order to service another, more distant university, doesn't seem like the best idea? Beyond the busing problem, in the years I've lived here, the neighbors have gotten worse and worse. It's a constant party in most of the buildings until the late hours of the night, no matter what day of the week it is. There are disgustingly huge and rowdy parties at the pool, the clubhouse, anywhere, including just people who mill about in loud and rude groups in the street that runs through the complex, or who run their cars and blast music and honk past midnight. Not many tenants seem to respect anymore that people have work or school, and not only that, but the courtesy officer set up to supposedly help us with noise concerns never seems to be available. I've called multiple times for loud disturbances and noises, and only once ever received a notification that they were asked to turn things down. Tenants keep loud animals and don't clean up after them, throw insane parties all hours of the day, and are in general becoming more and more rude, unsafe and rowdy, and the management doesn't seem to be doing much to stop it. In other words, this place has gone from a complex I used to recommend to my friends to one I now tell people to stay away from.

2008 - 2010 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/07/2010
My roommate and I moved to The Verge in August of 2008 and stayed for 2 years. The staff and everything was great the first year we were there. There was a change in management after our first year. However after staying there for a few months we noticed that we were paying close to double what other residents were paying. The only benefits to staying there is that if you are a Carolina student you have a great shuttle service, the shuttle to NCCU was not nearly as good as the service to Carolina. Another benefit is that all of your bills are included in your rent. The parking arrangement is awful. They have adequate parking yet require all visitors to park in a visitor's spot of which there are about 20 on the entire property. Also the towing company they have a contract with is 45 minutes away from the apartment. So not only do you have to pay to get your car back, but have to find a way to get there. The office staff does not care about talking to you or even helping with problems that you have. They were not attentive at all, and tend to give you what you ask for and walk of hurriedly back to their desks that are across the room. They were not welcoming or inviting. However they will send you a e-mail about everything. I really didn't need notification of the high amount of noise complaints. I could hear the noise and I could hear when the constant parties were broken up. Also once they got received our notice to vacate they no longer cared to fix any maintenance issues. We might as well have moved out when we turned in the form. Move out day was the worst. I felt like I was living in a dorm because everyone was moving at the same time. This also led to everyone turning in their keys at the same time. We were also ripped off on our final inspection which we received no notice of that resulted in loosing over half of our deposit over ridiculous expenses.

I went to the office after trying to talk to her and they acted like they couldn't do anything. The lady kept saying, Well you signed a contract and we can't get in the middle of your problems. She also had a very nasty attitude with me. They have this personality profile sheet but honestly that does not help if you don't really know who you are living with. The problems with my roommate continue. We(all the roommates) tried to have a meeting with Jessica and it just made matters worse. If I want to transfer to another apartment, I have to pay $200. Why, I don't know. Also, Jessica says that according to the contract a resident can have a visitor over(spending the night) for seven days. As long as the person leaves the 8th day, it is not violating the contract. So to me, it seems like someone can basically a guest can live in your apartment and you can't do anything about it. I tried to email the regional manager, but she has yet to answer me. My last hope is just to move out early and pay the rest of the money for the lease. Depending on where you live, there is no noise. Although, if you park near the visitor's section you may hear people with loud music driving by. I could also hear my roommate's tv and her talking since I live right in front of her(would not recommend a 3 bedroom). There was also a break in(car) a couple of weeks ago. In fact, today I had to drive to school because one of the van's registration had expired?!? How does this happen, if the management is doing their jobs. Overall, it is a nice apartment but the staff is terrible. Getting a one bedroom somewhere else would be cheaper than just renting one room here in a three bedroom apartment.

Resident
2004 - 2007 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/16/2009
I stayed at the Verge for 3 years during my undergrad and grad school, and really loved it. Having W/D in unit (and included in rent price) is very convenient. I got my own bathroom (which is FAR better than any complex around UNC), and the kitchen has all the amenities anyone could want. Since I renewed twice, my rent stayed the same, which is a far better deal. Watch out for the renewal deadlines to get the best deals. They usually offered bonuses like gift cards or pro-rated discounts on rent for renewing by certain deadlines, usually 4 months in advance. When I first began living here, no pets were allowed, and they transitioned to allow them but with strict financial policies, to divert those who might carelessly have a pet on the property. I never had issues with neighbors' pets being noisy. I did call the cops once when there was an extremely raucous party (out on the basketball court) and I will say that two people were taken away in cuffs, but that was a VERY rare circumstance and I would not even have called except the hollering kept getting louder (and it was already 4am, and they'd kept me up all night). Parties vary depending on the building you're in -- I had relatively quiet neighbors with that one exception during my 2nd year of living there. Overall, I'd recommend the Verge for any undergrad/grad of UNC -- other universities, it's not so convenient. But think about it this way: In traditional apartment complexes, you have to pay to get utility services turned on, and your bill will vary each month. At the verge, everything is included, there's no utility service fee to get it all started, and if you ever have a problem, there is no extra service charge to fix anything. They were always prompt to my maintenance requests (few, if any), and the one time we had a plumbing issues, they called emergency maintenance and got it fixed right away, including ripping out the cabinet under the kitchen sink and replacing the wood (to prevent mold). What's included: basic cable (about 70 channels), electricity (there is a monthly allowance, read your lease and be careful), water, sewer, INTERNET!!, washer/dryer (also very rare in apartment communities), trash, basketball court, generously sized pool, beach volleyball court, car wash station, FREE bus to UNC's campus, and maintenance at any time, no matter what the problem. I read some other reviews and was disturbed by references to racism by employees. I never experienced this, nor did any other (multi races involved) friends who lived there. Office staff changes on an annual basis, because many of the agents are actually residents there, but I found the management to be friendly and even though I had a few maintenance issues and a utility charge dispute (explained below), we were always on good terms. Remember, its easier to attract bees with honey... and it will keep you on good terms with ANY apartment management, no matter where you are, who you are, or anything else that might predispose them to some sort of opinion. I also read a review about the Verge not trying to attract NCCU students-- lets suffice it to say that this complex is more centered around UNC campus activities (hence the bus to campus on a 30 minute schedule, buses to UNC football/basketball, and Franklin St). Knowing this, I'm not sure why anyone would think that it is the Verge's mission to attract NCCU students, but I certainly understand the office staff talking about ways to attract more UNC students -- this helps the management to save money on expenses on things like the bus! Big PLUS about the Verge: if you have roommates when you move in, but over the course of a few years, people graduate (etc), and you need a new roommate, you are NEVER responsible for the additional rooms in your unit. In addition, the way the lease is written about the electricity allowance, make sure you read it -- they tried to charge me once for a utility overage when one of our bedrooms in a 3 bedroom unit was vacant, and we submitted the paperwork along with a copy of the lease and they rescinded the charges. Read the fine print so you know what you're getting into, ANYWHERE that claims utilities are included. It was not a problem for us, despite the additional paperwork, which only took a few days to resolve. This is a HUGE plus over any other apartment communities around Chapel Hill OR Durham. Just think -- that 500 (or so) per person includes EVERYTHING -- and if you live any other places around Chapel Hill, you'd split rent around 300-375 per month, and utilities would all be extra (probably 250 per month in total, split among roommates), and you'd have to find your own way to campus (and chapel hill transit is a LOT more unreliable than the Verge bus). 15 minute bus ride, plus game days, plus "party bus" on certain evenings (check the published schedule)... CAN'T BEAT IT!!!!

Resident
2007 - 2008 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/07/2008
The apartments are fairly new and have a lot of updated features. It's nice (and rare) to find a place with three bedrooms and three separate baths. Also, the bedrooms and especially the baths are a nice size. The kitchen and living room, on the other hand, are really small, and there's no space for a dining area and very little storage. They provide a shuttle bus to take people back and forth to campus, but they neglect to tell you that the bus runs on a pretty lousy schedule. It's fine while undergrad classes are in normal session, but once it hits exam time or a break, the bus runs much less frequently or stops running at all. It's a pretty bad set-up for graduate or professional students. So if you don't have a car and NEED to rely on public transportation, you'd be out of luck here. Parking is ok; you may not always get a space directly in front of your building, but there are enough spaces overall. The biggest problem with parking is that there is only one section for visitors, and it is in the far back corner of the complex. So visitors either have to walk a quarter mile to get to the spaces or they just park in resident spaces. It is not the quietest place because it is all students, so there will be parties, etc. Sometimes you can hear the upstairs neighbors entirely too well. Whether the noise is bad enough to be bothersome really depends on who your neighbors are. They also "include" utilities with the rent, but what this actually means is that they give you a quarterly allowance out of which to pay them. If you go over your quarterly allowance for your apartment, you have to pay the difference, but you would never be refunded if your utilities cost less. Even with the utilities allowance, $1600-$1800 is really a LOT to pay for a 3 bedroom that is miles from campus and not on ANY public busline. You could find a more spacious and convenient place for less money, and I would recommend that you look for one before deciding on The Verge.

Resident
2006 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/18/2006
I have lived at the Verge ever since it opened it's doors. The apartments are $500-600/month per person, which is expensive even by Chapel Hill standards, not to mention you actually live in DURHAM. Maintenance does take forever, even after repeated trips and phone calls to the office asking for help. While I have never had a HUGE problem that needed to be addressed, I do know that many people had cars spray painted and broken in to. They hired a security officer for awhile, but I haven't seen one in months...even after calling to report complaints. Though it is far from campus, the shuttle they offer ever 30 minutes is wonderful and it takes about 15 minutes to get to campus...at lease you are never late to class if you catch the right bus. It would be nice if all pet owners were in a separate building. The noise from running and barking dogs is very annoying. Also, since the pool is open 24 hours, the drunken screams outside my window really suck...often till 4am or later. I am in the process of moving out right now and will not really miss The Verge at all. It beats dorm living, but barely.

Resident
2004 - 2006 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/30/2006
I have lived at the Verge for two years now in the same apartment and I can honestly say I would not want to live anywhere else. Yes, it is pricier but not compared to apartments that are an equal level of quality nearer to campus. It is far from campus but the shuttle runs constantly and it is much closer to 40, the mall, target, restaurants, etc. I have only paid a utility overage once and it was 22 dollars despite the fact that we always have lights on and the AC turned way up! My rooom-mate lives under the stairs and she does complain about them so I would say that if you are light sleeper investigate the apartments and don't pick a bedroom under the stairs! Management can be a little snotty but I have found that if you are firm and upfront with you, I have always gotten what I needed out of them. The pool is great and if you bring charcoal you can always grill, even if the tanks are out. Parking can be a little tricky late at night (sometimes you have to park in visitors) and they should tow more often but when I have had overnight guests I am glad that they don't! I have only had to call maintenance 3 times in 2 years (always from my long hair clogging the drain) and they are prompt especially if you remind them! I have never had my car broken into or anything stolen although I have seen the police cars patrolling. Also, I think people haven't gotten their mail because they forget to put their apartment number on them, I've never had a problem. I love the Verge and wish I didn't have to leave . . .

2005 - 2006 Not Recommended Reviewed 01/10/2006
TAKE YOUR MONEY ELSEWHERE. While they keep the complex clean and flashy, the verge management is wholly incompetent. They try to seduce you with spring break trips, parties, and the campus shuttle but they don't have it where it counts. Four examples (1) while they do have a computer lab, the computers are often on the fritz. At one point, the lab had only 2 computers working with internet. Frustrating when everyone was scrambling for computers after constant internet problems throughout the complex. (2) My internet went down for a month during midterms; I complained consistently calling 4 times in a 3-week period. They only responded to my requests after I contacted student legal services and emailed them with a carbon copy sent to my lawyer. They got my internet up fast, but refused to offer any abatement. (3) Inadequate security has led to the theft of 2 packages off my front door valued at around 110 dollars. Make sure you get your packages delivered to the front office. Maintenance is SLOW. Problems take about a week and a half to get fixed. Don't hold your breath, get proficient with a wrench. I would not be as annoyed if the rent was not so high. I expect better service from a "luxury" apartment complex. It is clear the Verge only wants your money, (and they have the audacity to raise rent to 595 next semester for the 3BR furnished) stay the hell away if you know what is good for you. DO NOT RENT HERE, RUN AWAY. There are better deals out there. Terrible experience.
TAKE YOUR MONEY ELSEWHERE. While they keep the complex clean and flashy, the verge management is wholly incompetent. They try to seduce you with spring break trips, parties, and the campus shuttle but they don't have it where it counts. Four examples (1) while they do have a computer lab, the computers are often on the fritz. At one point, the lab had only 2 computers working with internet. Frustrating when everyone was scrambling for computers after constant internet problems throughout the complex. (2) My internet went down for a month during midterms; I complained consistently calling 4 times in a 3-week period. They only responded to my requests after I contacted student legal services and emailed them with a carbon copy sent to my lawyer. They got my internet up fast, but refused to offer any abatement. (3) Inadequate security has led to the theft of 2 packages off my front door valued at around 110 dollars. Make sure you get your packages delivered to the front office. Maintenance is SLOW. Problems take about a week and a half to get fixed. Don't hold your breath, get proficient with a wrench. I would not be as annoyed if the rent was not so high. I expect better service from a "luxury" apartment complex. It is clear the Verge only wants your money, (and they have the audacity to raise rent to 595 next semester for the 3BR furnished) stay the hell away if you know what is good for you. DO NOT RENT HERE, RUN AWAY. There are better deals out there. Terrible experience. Read less

2004 - 2005 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/21/2005
While the Verge is a fairly new complex and competitively priced the facade ends there...because along with those amenities you also get a staff that doesn't ever want to be bothered, is terriblely unorganized, and responds to tenants needs slower than FEMA in New Orleans. During my year living in their apartment I had bug problems twice which were never fixed, and an explosive waterpipe in my bathroom that was supposedly repaired but leaked water all year. In addition, the apartments are still settling, so the stoves are not level and my bathroom and bedroom doors did not close completely as a result. The new all-inclusive package is even more than advertised as I was billed double my utility charge as was my roommate three times. In addition, the propane tanks on the grills at the pool and basketball courts are almost always empty, so don't get excited about grilling out. Parking is a nightmare because the complex doesn't enforce towing. It is extremely inexpensive relative to other apartments in the area, but expect a level of customer service that makes Walmart look good. Overall I wouldn't recommend living there, if you are a UNC student pay the extra money to live near campus in the Warehouse because it is nicer and the staff is excellent or even pay extra to live in Chancellor's square which isn't as nice, but has much better service by the rental agency.

Leasing

Welcome to Haven at Patterson Place Apartments, luxury living in Durham, NC. With a convient location near I-40 and NC 15-501, an address at Haven at Patterson Place offers easy access to Raleigh, Chapel Hill, Downtown Durham as well as UNC-Chapel Hill and Duke University. With Patterson Place Shopping Mall nearby, you'll find that everything you need is just within reach! Our open-concept one, two and three bedroom apartment homes are thoughtfully appointed with gourmet kitchens with breakfast bars, faux-wood plank flooring, full-size washer and dryer, private patio or balcony and each bedroom has a private bathroom. These features are also included in our three bedroom townhomes! Our community offers a swimming pool, sand volleyball court, basketball court, game room with billiards, fitness center, outdoor grilling area and resident louge. Contact one of our on-site leasing professionals today to secure your new home!

Management Company: Bell Partners, Inc.

Office Hours Open Now!

  • Sunday: 01:00 PM - 05:00 PM
  • Monday - Friday: 09:00 AM - 06:00 PM
  • Saturday: 10:00 AM - 05:00 PM
